chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A broadly acceptable reform is to keep state-run elections but reduce winner-take-all distortions by requiring a uniform proportional allocation of electors within each state, with a clear, nationally consistent method for recounts and certification. Add strong integrity and legitimacy measures—paper ballots or voter-verified paper records, routine post-election audits, and binding elector laws—so results are verifiable and accepted. After multiple cycles of demonstrated reliability, states could choose to activate a national popular-vote mechanism (via compact or amendment) with agreed thresholds, while using ranked-choice ballots to ensure the winner has broad support.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Pursue a phased reform that keeps states administering elections but makes outcomes better match the national popular will: bind electors to certified results and reduce winner‑take‑all by moving to proportional or district-based allocation, while allowing a National Popular Vote interstate compact to take effect once broad state adoption is reached. Pair any structural change with uniform baseline standards for ballot access, paper-backed voting, recount triggers, and routine post‑election audits to improve legitimacy. Consider ranked-choice voting where feasible to reduce spoiler effects and ensure the winner reflects broad support.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: A durable compromise should keep states running elections but make presidential outcomes better match the will of voters: curb winner‑take‑all by moving to proportional or district-based elector allocation, bind electors to certified results, and allow a National Popular Vote compact only once uniform, auditable standards are in place. Establish national baselines for ballot access, paper-backed voting, clear recount triggers, and routine post‑election audits to improve trust and reduce partisan gamesmanship. To ensure winners have broad support and give independents and third parties a fair shot without spoilers, states should be encouraged to adopt ranked‑choice voting alongside these changes.
